importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The outage occurred on October 20, 2025, at 07:11 GMT, marking a pivotal moment when AWS services failed, affecting global digital infrastructure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage lasted approximately three hours, from 07:11 to 10:11 GMT, during which critical AWS services failed and impacted numerous major apps and websites.

keyTakeAways: An error in a technical update to DynamoDB’s API caused a DNS failure, disrupting access to the cloud database.
The root cause was a DNS malfunction due to a flawed update, which prevented apps from finding the correct server addresses.
The outage affected 113 AWS services, including major platforms such as Snapchat, Pinterest, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Apple TV, Starbucks, Duolingo, Canva, and financial apps like Venmo.
Banks, airlines (Delta, United), cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase, AI firm Perplexity, and news outlets (AP, NYT, WSJ) were also impacted.
The outage highlighted how deeply dependent modern digital infrastructure is on AWS, with many companies relying on its cloud services for operations.
Experts, including Joshua Mahony and Bryson Bort, confirmed that the issue stemmed from human error, not a cyberattack.
AWS engineers responded quickly, restoring services by 10:11 GMT, though a backlog of messages remained to be processed.
AWS acknowledged the issue, deployed multiple recovery paths, and committed to releasing a detailed post-mortem report.

summaryOfNewsArticle: An outage at Amazon Web Services (AWS) on October 20, 2025, caused widespread disruptions to a wide array of internet services, including major apps like Snapchat, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, and financial platforms such as Venmo and Coinbase. The root cause was a technical error during a software update to DynamoDB’s API, which triggered a DNS failure, preventing apps from locating server addresses. This cascaded failure affected 113 AWS services and highlighted the critical dependence of modern digital infrastructure—ranging from banking and gaming to media and smart home devices—on cloud computing. Experts confirmed that the incident stemmed from human error, not a cyberattack. AWS responded swiftly, restoring services by 10:11 GMT, though some users faced delays due to a backlog of messages. The event underscores the fragility and interdependence of global digital systems, even as AWS maintains a dominant market share and robust recovery capabilities.
title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
